Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: I was just about to grab my toolbox when my phone buzzed. It was my partner, voice trembling, asking if I could talk. They’d been offered a new position at work, but the decision was tearing them up inside. I could hear the anxiety in every word, and I knew they needed me—needed my reassurance, my advice, my presence. But as I glanced at the maintenance log, my stomach tightened. Three machines had missed their last service, and now they were running dangerously hot. If I didn’t get to them soon, we could be looking at a costly breakdown, maybe even a halt in production. My supervisor had already warned me about the importance of keeping everything running smoothly. I felt pulled in two directions—my partner’s voice in my ear, desperate for comfort, and the machines humming in the background, demanding my immediate attention. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between being the supportive spouse I wanted to be and the reliable repairer everyone expected.
